Next to the slasher films of the 1970s and 80s, ones about the walking dead were probably the second most popular horror sub-genre in modern times. The success of George A. Romero’s Night Of The Living Dead from back in 1968 proved that there was a market for zombie-themed exploitation films, which soon led many other filmmakers and producers to cash in on their new-found popularity.

Reading through these comments, I see a remarkable socio-cultural clash theme emerging between the US and... the Dutch! The US expresses a sense of entitlement to sit where it wants to - "waiting my turn" -, while the Dutch continue with their conviction that "any queue is a waiting queue"... one must be prepared for anything, anything! at any place.

The Bone Snatcher is about a group miners who go on a search for a missing crew of miners in the Namib Desert. When the find them, they do not realize that an alien organism called Vaterra has killed them and turned them into camouflage monsters that never stop moving. Unfortunately for our heroes, they have already been infected by this alien organism. They turn on their own co-workers until only two are left to battle the creatures.

While credited as a Tom and Jerry cartoon, this is not the cat-and-mouse team but an earlier Mutt-and-Jeff rip-off featuring them going about to survive in today's turbulent economy. In the end, they channel their problems over into other aspects of their lives until they are engulfed in payback wrath by another group of stick-up victims. (The wild-eyed ones with two spoons cut up into a heart shape on their faces were a great touch.)

Snow White is in my opinion a bad movie on an artistic point of view. The plot is pretty much foreseeable, the characters are stereotypes, the editing too. But it’s got vibes that pulls you in and reminds me of your favorite Tarantino movies as Pulp Fiction or Reservoir Dogs or a pretty traditional martial arts korean movie like I Saw The Devil.

Michael Dudikoff stars as Joe Armstrong a martial artist who fights ninjas who are stealing weapons from the U.S Army, in this entertaining yet admittedly brainless comedic action film. This film is clearly an attempt to create a cult phenomenon like the John Woo Bruce Lee martial arts films of the Sixties and Seventies.
